text: hi everyone Anthony Phan tanto here
intranets busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Daniel
Avery album drone logic before we get
into this LP I know some of you are
still a little sad still a little down
in the dumps but hey come on it's
another day another album to listen to
put a smile on your face it's alright
man chill I love you Daniel Avery is a
uk-based electronic music producer he
has released this full-length debut of
his drone logic right here on fantasy
records earlier this year and I was
pretty impressed with what this guy was
doing with techno and house music from a
technical and from a sonic standpoint I
wouldn't say Daniel Avery is reinventing
the wheel here or violently burning down
the status quo even though he's not
blowing me away with a really
experimental take on these genres he is
delivering a very long album a very well
assembled tracks the beats on this LP
have a lot of rigid robotic techno
characteristics but are still undeniable
to the hips a lot of Drive in these
rhythms and I think the bass lines are
especially bouncy it's really nice to
hear beats that have such a synthetic
aesthetic but still appeal to those very
deep got to move to this primal
instincts there are quite a few vocal
snippets on this thing moments like
Walter Jones weird little cuts of spoken
word that play throughout a lot of these
tracks for the most part the vocals add
to the very stone-faced
near emotionless vibes that this album
gives off through a lot of its sounds
even these sustain singing notes on the
opening track here that are sampled and
looped over and over and over are
manipulated and distorted and feel so
grainy that they are just merely a shell
of their former selves in terms of
feeling human anyway the most tender
vocal cut on this entire LP is the
whispered singing on the closing track
knowing we'll be here it's pretty nice
to hear a techno album an electronic
music album that starts off so just
lockstep and chilly war
month as it progresses relatively anyway
like on the very gently pulsating soft
and melodic tracks Samuel wreck or the
track new energy which gets
progressively more and more intense and
noisy and fiery as it goes on with a
very krautrock inspired beat and there
are a lot of sharp and noisy drones that
occur on some of these tracks to adding
a bit of emotional heat and intensity as
far as the melodies go on this LP and
the counterpoint with the bass lines and
some of the synth chords that pop up
Daniel Avery's approach is very simple
but there is purpose here because all of
these elements do add up into some
catchy synth sequences or just a really
potent moody mix of sounds and
structurally these tracks justify five
six seven eight minutes song lengths
with the theory that if you start out
with a great groove you can keep things
interesting by varying the rhythms
dropping out ideas introducing new ideas
or slowly layering tracks for a gradual
climax and even though drone logic to an
extent is easy to sum up as an album it
doesn't take away from the magic and the
tension of listening to these songs in
the moment like the song water jump
which has multiple phases and all of
them leave me feeling like I'm listening
to the soundtrack to driving at night at
very high speed through a neon lit City
1000 years into the future and things
get especially epic when a few very
grainy minor tone chords enter the
picture on top and already growing pile
of beats synth leads vocal samples and
some ba-ba-ba-ba-ba bass and some tracks
do hit harder than others with some very
punchy rhythms and hard ass bass like
the song naive response whose low end is
very heavy and rubbery as the song
progresses with its bassline just
bouncing over and over and over or the
song these nights never end whose groove
is very lightly kissed with these sharp
distorted oddly placed since sequences
and these eerily sustain notes I will
say that the Assembly of sounds on this
LP lacks a certain finesse that you
might find in the productions of an R
like John Hopkins or Pantha new prints
however I do kind of enjoy the hard
entrances and exits of new sounds and
ideas on these songs because it does add
to the already enjoyably rigid
characteristics that these songs have to
offer and while there are some sharp
noisy drones on these tracks that I do
like and I did kind of expect given that
the name of this album his drone logic
for the most part the drones do feel
more like an accent or a side dish not a
main attraction the most spotlight a
drone gets on this LP is on the 1-minute
interlude tracks spring 27 and even
though the drones do add character to
this LP they're not exactly enough to
save some of these tracks from their
very very repetitive selves like the
song all I need where even though the
drone is entering the picture and
changing things up slightly there's not
enough variation in the instrumentation
underneath that to kind of keep things
feeling tense and the song all I need is
well to me is is lacking in a bit of
drive to progress and kind of change the
sound of this song as it plods along so
yeah there are a few tracks on here that
do feel a little less developed a little
less detailed than others and I did
think the clothes are on here while good
was sort of anticlimactic for a
finishing track that and the fact that I
felt like there really could have been a
little more sonic adventure going on
with these tracks these were the only
major issues I had with this album
though again I don't think Daniel Avery
is reinventing the wheel here he has put
together a series of very very well
crafted techno tracks with great grooves
rhythms bass lines since sequences I am
feeling a strong seven to a light eight
on this thing
transition but if you've given this up
he'll listen what did you think
why am i whispering what should i review
next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh
Daniel every drone logic forever
